docs.lead_paragraph: Maxine Smith, a friend and neighbor in Boston, had not heard from Leon Gray for close to a week, and began to wonder, if not worry. It was not unusual for Gray, a 6-foot-4, 280-pound former offensive tackle for the New England Patriots, to vanish for periods of time. Gray, who would have turned 50 last week, might move and not tell anyone. He would change his telephone number and not tell anyone. His eight surviving siblings, each living here in the Memphis area where he grew up, had not heard from him in 14 years. A former teammate might run into Gray while waiting for a red light in Boston, honk the car horn, exchange pleasantries and Gray would promise to get in touch, and would not.

headline.main: A Competitor Who Withdrew From the Game

docs.abstract: Article profiles Leon Gray, top offensive lineman who played for New England Patriots; Gray died in November; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Nov. 20 letter from a psychiatrist emphasizes the need for mental health parity legislation, a need dramatized by the aftermath of Sept. 11. Earlier this year, the New York State Assembly passed comprehensive parity legislation that would require insurance and managed-care coverage for mental illnesses and substance abuse on the same basis as the carrier's coverage for physical ailments. No longer would the insurance industry be permitted to discriminate against those with mental illness in terms of coverage, co-payments, days of service or other loopholes that exist in current law.
docs.abstract: Letter from New York State Assemblyman Martin A Luster on need for legislation that would require insurance and managed-care coverage for mental illnesses on same basis as carrier's coverage for physical ailments; notes such a bill is pending in New York State Senate

docs.lead_paragraph: Owners of small businesses in New Jersey are more pessimistic about their prospects for the coming year than they have been in any year since the early 1990's, according to survey results by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. But their gloom is not nearly as deep as it was a decade ago. About two-thirds of the 1,600 small-business owners who participated in the association's 43rd annual Business Outlook Survey said their industries had entered a recession or were heading into one, twice as many as said so last year. According to results released this week, almost half of those surveyed said they expected New Jersey's economy to worsen in the first half of 2002, twice as many as those who said last year that they expected a weaker economy at the beginning of 2001.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Kay Ash, who built a billion-dollar beauty empire from a $5,000 investment in 1963, and who motivated hundreds of thousands of consultants around the world with a combination of rewards, recognition and religion, died yesterday at her home in Dallas. She was 83. She died of natural causes, said Jim Lawrence, a spokesman for Mary Kay Inc. in Dallas. Mrs. Ash had been in frail health since she suffered a stroke in 1996.

headline.main: Mary Kay Ash, Who Built a Cosmetics Empire and Adored Pink, Is Dead at 83

docs.lead_paragraph: Hugo Moyano, the Teamsters union leader, called for a national civil disobedience campaign to protect health insurance for pensioners and wage bonuses. The protests would also oppose a plan he says the government is preparing that would replace the peso with the dollar. With the government struggling to meet payments on its $132 billion debt, Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo and other senior officials recently said they would prefer dollarization to a major devaluation in the event of a total financial collapse. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Come the spring, the White House chief of staff, Andrew Card, will move to Massachusetts to compete for the Republican nomination for governor. (The race is not always to the Swift.) This is Card's lifelong ambition, and maybe the entry of a fresh face will stop the slide of G.O.P.-held statehouses into Democratic hands. He will be replaced in that top political power slot by Tom Ridge, the former Pennsylvania governor who is now grimly trying to run ''homeland security'' from the president's side without the needed muscle to knock departmental heads together.

docs.lead_paragraph: Allstate is suing 40 people who collected more than $1 million in medical claims in traffic accidents that were later alleged to have been staged. The civil suit, filed in Morris County Superior Court on Tuesday, accuses the defendants of fraudulently staging nine accidents and then seeking medical attention at Allied Trauma and Health Care of Essex County. Allstate won a $5.35 million judgment against Allied Trauma, which closed in 1999 and is not named in the current suit.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Lawsuit In Suspicious Accidents
